Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 05:05AM Karen09 wrote: I had FEC-T - four treatments of FEC and then four of Taxotere.  After I finished the FEC, my hair started to grow back and it never fell out again with the taxotere.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Did anyone had her hair back after taxotere??? melania janet11

Posts.Content: Karen09 wrote: Hi ladies!  I just wanted to share this with you all and brighten your day a little.  I was diagnosed with Stage 3 metaplastic triple negative breast cancer last year and I've been on this site a lot since then.  Maybe you have seen me sneaking in to post from time to time.  Anyway, after my second chemo I found the most beautiful long hair stray cat out behind my apartment building and I took him in.  I couldn't find his owners (thank god!) so I kept him and he was so good to me when I was sick.  He never left my side on my bad days and was so wanting to play and have a good time on my good days.  He really touched my heart and I was interviewed by Purina Cat Chow about him not too long ago.  They are doing a big donation to BC and a campaign next month about how cats can help ladies through BC.  Here are the first two articles on the interview.  A video should follow at some point too.   http://pets.savvy-cafe.com/cats-comfort-breast-cancer-patients-2010-09-07/ http://www.emcorleans.ca/20100916/Lifestyle/Cats+comfort+breast+cancer+patients Dx 6/8/2009, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIIA, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 04:48AM Karen09 wrote: My lumpectomy was a breeze really.  I had a general.  I didn't really know what to expect but I had very little pain afterwards, less than I expected.  Just a dull ache from time to time and I didn't even really need to take anything for it.  I had a lot of bruising but that went away and the incision healed nicely.  No complications, no problems.  If you have any questions, feel free to send me a message.  I hope yours is as easy as mine was.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy~ ur experience Deanna67 Deanna67

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 04:50AM Karen09 wrote: Oh and I went home a few hours after I woke up.  They gave me something to eat and drink before I left to make sure and then by supper time I was really hungry and had a huge bowel of soup.  Later on the evening I went for a nice slow walk with a friend and stopped for a big ice cream on the way home.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2010 07:07AM Karen09 wrote: When I first started chemo I had the worst craving for potatoes - I thought it was a bit odd and just couldn't get enough of them.  I had more potatoes those first two months that I have for years.  lol!  Then when I got tired of them - it was just any vegetable in general.  I remember getting so excited over cauliflower being on sale once.  haha!  Then after I got a bit tired of veggies, it was on to noodles noodles noodles.

Posts.Content: Karen09 wrote: Hi, I just have a quick question.  Is anyone getting just taxotere?  I'm just wondering how long it takes to get the treatment?  Just trying to plan for someone to sit with me through it and it would help to know how long it will take.  I just hate sitting through chemo by myself and a lot of my friends work so it's a bit difficult sometimes.  I just finished four FEC treatments and I'm moving on to Taxotere at the end of the month.  Halfway through!  Thanks to anyone who responds! Dx 6/8/2009, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIIA, 0/7 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere question Karen09 Karen09

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 03:43AM Karen09 wrote: Hi Rackie.  I had 4 FEC and 4 taxotere last year.  I did get quite sick with my first treatment but they changed my meds around the second time and I never did get that sick again.  I had emend and a steroid and I think they really made the difference.  I did get nauseated with the next three FEC but not nearly as bad as the first.  If I had any tips it would be to drink lots of fluids and take a laxative on the first couple days.  It helps to have a glass of water beside you and sip from it from time to time if you don't feel up to drinking a full glass all the time.  I also had neulasta and I didn't have any side effects at all with it.  Hopefully you won't either. Hang in there!  You can do this!  I'll be pulling for you!
Posts.Title: anyone have FEC-T chemo rackie carofin

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 07:35AM Karen09 wrote: I did 4 treatments of FEC and 4 of Taxotere from August to the end of December last year.  My cancer was metaplastic triple negative Stage 3 so my oncologist wanted an aggressive chemo.  She also prefers FEC.  I'm in Canada too so it's a bit more common here.  My side effects were a lot of what people mentioned already.  Nausea over the first couple days, fatigue.  My sense of smell was quite extreme off and on and I did get a couple mouth sores and a whitish colour on my tongue.  I found using an alcohol free mouthwash and sensodyne toothpaste helped.  I didn't have much of an appetite for the first couple days but it came back with a vengeance afterwards.  I lost all my hair quickly but it started growing again when I started the taxotere so that was very nice.  Good luck to you all having treatments right now!  I survived mine and finished rads in March.  Hang in there ladies!  You can do this!
Posts.Title: Anyone having FEC? ducky1 SKD

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 02:00PM Karen09 wrote: I had 7 nodes removed and they all ended up being negative.  My surgeon said the dye didn't show up for the sentinel node so she had to take 7 nodes.  They looked enlarged to her but they were just inflammed because of the dye starting to work.  Anyway, it's been a year so far and I haven't had any problems with lymphedema at all (knock on wood!).
Posts.Title: Totally confused about sentinel node biopsy results LtotheK LtotheK

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 10:17AM Karen09 wrote: Hi Jen, it doesn't hurt to get it checked out for sure.  Hopefully your doc will be able to put your mind at ease or run some tests.  It's hard to be finished your treatment and then have to worry about aches and pains.  I'll be thinking about you!    Karen (your old chemo day buddy from the August Amazon thread!)
Posts.Title: WORRIED & NEED TO TELL SOMEONE jenn3 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2010 10:09PM Karen09 wrote: Hey ladies!!  I was part of the August group of last year and just wanted to say "hi" and tell you ladies to hang in there.  I had a lumpectomy last year, was diagnosed with triple negative metaplastic stage 3 in June, had a partial mastectomy with negative lymph node dissection in July and then had chemo August until the end of December (4 FEC & 4 taxotere) and then 21 radiation treatments in February and March.  That's my story and I just want you to know that you will get through this.  It won't be easy at times but you will get through it!!  I am 15 months out from my diagnosis - I'm back to work full time, have my life and my health back.  I just get tired sometimes still but I feel great considering.  And I now have a full head of hair again!  HANG IN THERE AND KEEP YOUR CHINS UP!!  Hugs to you all!!!
Posts.Title: August 2010...anyone starting chemo besides me?! 1WonderWoman 1WonderWoman

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 08:20AM Karen09 wrote: My oncologist recommended both shots.
Posts.Title: H1N1 Vaccine Firelady pip57

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 01:08PM Karen09 wrote: Well breast cancer is more rare when you are in your 20s BUT I think you should push until you know for sure. You would regret it if you didn't and it did turn out to be cancer. Plus it would give you peace of mind to know for sure either way. My doctor told me breast cancer is rare in young women when I was 31 and seeing her for the lump in my breast. Turned out to be cancer though.
Posts.Title: only 29 do I need to worry about breast cancer? cmurtaugh Deep81

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 02:22PM Karen09 wrote: Hi, I was diagnoses with stage 3 aggressive and all that last year.  I had 2 surgeries, 8 chemo and 21 radiation and now I'm cancer free and doing great.  Hang in there.  Waiting is the hardest part and don't forget to look after you.  If your body tells you it needs a rest, listen to it.  Drink plenty of fluids during chemo.  Hang in there and lean on your friends and family.  This board is a great place for support so take advantage of that too.  I'll be thinking about you and send me a private message if you ever need anything.
Posts.Title: Recently Diagnosed - Need Strength and Encouragement BLC momand2kids

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 07:04AM Karen09 wrote: I am a year and eight months past my diagnosis - I was triple negative metaplastic and I'm doing great.  My energy is back and I have a lot of hair.  Hang in there and try not to let people bring you down.  It isn't easy going through treatment but it will get better.  Focus on the positive, focus on getting through every week.  These boards are great when you are feeling down and need some sisterly support.  I still feel like none of my friends understand my worry and not doing what the future will bring but it helps to know there are lots of people out there that do.  Live love laugh!  Sending you a hug!
Posts.Title: Going through Chemo and need support Braveheart Braveheart

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 06:12AM Karen09 wrote: Hi Blieuxgirl I'm 31 and I just had a lumpectomy this past May.  I wasn't sure what to expect at all but it really wasn't a big deal.  I had a little pain afterward but it wasn't even enough to take any pain medication for.  My surgeon told me I would have a small dent in my breast afterwards since my lump had grown to 8 cms but she said it would gradually fill in with tissue over time - and it has already.  I know how stressful this all is and I won't tell you "not to worry" but try to be positive.  Hopefully it is nothing and you won't need any further treatment after the lumpectomy.  I'll be thinking about you and let me know if you have any questions.  And let us know how you make out!  Take care
Posts.Title: having lumpectomy not sure of pathology blieuxgirl blieuxgirl

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 05:43AM Karen09 wrote: It certainly does Sheila.  I never thought I would be like this before this all started.  I'm with you on the pants thing though!  hehe!
Posts.Title: Who Knew??? Trabby Debonthelake

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 12:41PM Karen09 wrote: Hi Trabby.  I was really shy about my body before this all started too.  It really didn't take very long for me not to care and I just whip my shirt and bra off and on for doctors and technicians lickety split now.  I want to get in and out of my appointments as quickly and smoothly as possible so I can get back to my life. I work in the hospital where I had all my treatments and I actually work with my surgeon.  I figure after two ultrasounds, two biopsies, a mammogram, an MRI, two surgeries and not to mention God knows how many doctors/medical professionals poking around my chest, that half the entire hospital has probably seen me topless by now.  And you know what?  I just don't care anymore!  Now if it was a cancer I had to take my pants off for, it would probably be a different story.  LOL!  Just take it one day at a time and try not to worry too much - easier said than done, I know.  Hopefully your ultrasound will be the only test you need and you will get a clean bill of health with just a simple cyst.  Good luck!  I'll be thinking about you and wishing you well!
